colors.primary: Silvery-grey on the dorsal side, transitioning to silvery-white on the ventral side.
colors.accents: Dark grey or black longitudinal stripes along the body, following scale rows.

patterns: 6-8 distinct dark grey or black longitudinal stripes running horizontally along the body, following the scale rows from behind the operculum to the caudal peduncle.
Faint darker shading may be present along the dorsal midline.
distinctive_features: Relatively small mouth with a thick upper lip.
Adipose eyelid partially covering the eye.
Two separate dorsal fins, the first with four spines, the second with one spine and 8-9 soft rays.
Pectoral fins positioned high on the body.
Caudal fin is forked.
visual_description.body_shape: Elongated, fusiform (torpedo-shaped) body, slightly compressed laterally. Body depth is moderate, not excessively deep or slender.
visual_description.prompt_additions: Silvery-grey mullet with dark longitudinal stripes. Two dorsal fins, forked tail, small mouth. Adipose eyelid.

colors.primary: Light grey to grey-brown dorsally, fading to white ventrally
colors.accents: Jet black tips on the first dorsal fin, pectoral fins, pelvic fins, anal fin, and lower lobe of the caudal fin. A thin, pale band often borders the black tips.

patterns: Prominent jet black tip on the first dorsal fin, covering the upper portion.
Jet black tip on the lower lobe of the caudal fin.
Jet black tips on the pectoral, pelvic, and anal fins.
Pale, often whitish, band bordering the black fin tips.
distinctive_features: Distinctive black tips on fins, especially the first dorsal fin.
Relatively short, rounded snout.
Moderately large, oval eyes with dark irises.
First dorsal fin originates over or slightly behind the pectoral fin free rear tips.
No interdorsal ridge.
visual_description.body_shape: Streamlined, fusiform body shape typical of requiem sharks. Moderately slender build.
visual_description.prompt_additions: Blacktip Reef Shark. Grey body, white underside. Black fin tips. Coral reef environment. Streamlined body. Short, rounded snout.

colors.secondary: Translucent, allowing internal organs to be partially visible
colors.accents: White or cream-colored bands on the abdomen; tips of pereiopods may be reddish

patterns: Transverse bands of slightly darker pink across the abdomen, creating a subtle striped effect
Small, scattered reddish-brown chromatophores (pigment cells) visible under magnification, giving a speckled appearance
distinctive_features: Rostrum (horn-like projection between the eyes) with 7-9 dorsal teeth and 2-3 ventral teeth
Well-developed pleopods (swimming legs) on the abdomen
Long, slender antennae, often exceeding the body length
Five pairs of pereiopods (walking legs), the first three pairs chelate (with claws)
visual_description.body_shape: Elongated, cylindrical body tapering towards the tail; slightly compressed laterally
visual_description.prompt_additions: Southern pink shrimp, Penaeus notialis, pale coral pink, translucent, long antennae, coral reef habitat

colors.accents: Red spots and markings on carapace

patterns: Scattered red spots on the dorsal surface of the carapace, concentrated towards the anterior region.
Irregular red markings along the lateral edges of the carapace.
distinctive_features: Paddle-shaped dactyls (last segment) on the fifth pair of pereiopods (legs), adapted for swimming.
Broad, flattened carapace with prominent anterolateral spines (likely 9 spines, typical of Callinectes genus).
Chelipeds (claws) are robust and significantly sized relative to the body.
visual_description.body_shape: Broad, flattened carapace, roughly oval in dorsal view. The carapace is wider than it is long. The body is dorsoventrally compressed, typical of swimming crabs.
visual_description.prompt_additions: Swimming crab, Callinectes bocourti, light brown carapace with red spots and markings, red claws and legs, paddle-shaped rear legs, broad carapace.

colors.primary: Bright blue head (males); Yellow body (initial phase)
colors.secondary: Black bars on sides (terminal phase males); White or pale yellow underside
colors.accents: Bright blue lips (males); Black spot behind the pectoral fin (initial phase)

patterns: Two vertical black bars on the sides, located behind the pectoral fin and mid-body (terminal phase males)
Yellow body coloration (initial phase)
Iridescent blue head (terminal phase males)
distinctive_features: Thick lips
Continuous dorsal fin running the length of the back
Elongated body shape
Bright blue head coloration in terminal phase males
Small size

visual_description.prompt_additions: Small, elongated fish. Bright blue head (males). Yellow body (initial phase). Black bars on sides (terminal phase males). Thick lips. Continuous dorsal fin. Coral reef environment.

colors.primary: Slate grey to dark grey dorsally, fading to white ventrally
colors.accents: Black trailing edge on caudal fin (tail), dark tips on pectoral, pelvic, and anal fins; white or plain first dorsal fin

patterns: Uniform grey coloration on the dorsal surface, transitioning smoothly to white on the ventral surface.
Distinct broad black margin along the posterior edge of the caudal fin.
distinctive_features: Broad, rounded snout.
Large, round eyes.
First dorsal fin is typically plain or white-tipped.
Lack of an interdorsal ridge (no ridge between the two dorsal fins).
Streamlined body shape typical of reef sharks.

visual_description.prompt_additions: Grey reef shark, Carcharhinus amblyrhynchos, dark grey dorsally, white underside, black-edged tail, reef shark shape, large eyes, no interdorsal ridge.

colors.secondary: Bright blue claws and legs, particularly prominent in males
colors.accents: White ventral surface; red tips on chelae (claws), especially in females

patterns: Carapace is generally a uniform olive-green to brownish-tan color.
Blue coloration is most intense on the outer surfaces of the claws and legs.
distinctive_features: Broad, flattened carapace with prominent lateral spines (points) on each side.
Paddle-shaped fifth pair of legs adapted for swimming.
Chelipeds (claws) are large and asymmetrical, with one claw often larger than the other.
Nine marginal teeth along the anterolateral margin of the carapace, including the lateral spine.
visual_description.body_shape: Broad, oval carapace with a flattened body. The carapace is wider than it is long.
visual_description.prompt_additions: American Blue Crab, Callinectes sapidus, olive-green carapace, bright blue claws, paddle-shaped rear legs, broad carapace with lateral spines, white underside, red claw tips (female)

colors.primary: Variable depending on life stage and sex. Initial phase (IP) typically dull reddish-brown to grey. Terminal phase (TP) males are vibrant blue-green.
colors.secondary: Pink to orange stripes and markings, especially prominent in TP males.
colors.accents: Bright blue or green edging on fins in TP males; yellow around the mouth in some phases.

patterns: Horizontal pink to orange stripes along the body, more pronounced in TP males.
Darker scale margins creating a net-like pattern, especially visible in IP individuals.
Blue or green edging on the dorsal, anal, and caudal fins in TP males.
distinctive_features: Fused beak-like teeth, often with a slightly protruding upper jaw.
Relatively large scales.
Rounded caudal fin (tail) in IP individuals, becoming more lunate (crescent-shaped) in TP males.
visual_description.body_shape: Elongate and robust, typical of parrotfishes. Slightly compressed laterally.
visual_description.prompt_additions: Striped parrotfish, Scarus iseri, vibrant blue-green terminal phase male, pink stripes, beak-like mouth, coral reef environment

colors.primary: Variable; can be pinkish-red, greenish-blue, or a combination of these colors depending on age and sex.
colors.secondary: Often a lighter shade of the primary color on the ventral side.
colors.accents: Black markings around the mouth and on the operculum (gill cover). Iridescent blue or green highlights may be present on scales.

patterns: A distinct reddish-brown or maroon band often present along the lateral line, especially prominent in juveniles and some females. This band may fade or become less distinct in mature males.
Dark blotches or irregular markings may be present on the flanks, particularly in individuals with a greenish-blue base color.
distinctive_features: Fused beak-like teeth, characteristic of parrotfish.
Relatively thick lips.
Robust, oval-shaped body.
Caudal fin (tail fin) is slightly rounded to lunate (crescent-shaped), becoming more lunate with age.
visual_description.body_shape: Oblong and compressed laterally, giving it a somewhat oval appearance. Robust build.
visual_description.prompt_additions: Redband Parrotfish, Sparisoma aurofrenatum, Caribbean reef fish, beak-like teeth, lateral red band, iridescent scales, robust body.

colors.primary: Light blue to bluish-grey dorsally, transitioning to yellow on the flanks and belly.
colors.secondary: Bright yellow stripe running laterally from the snout to the tail.
colors.accents: Small blue spots may be present on the upper flanks. Fins are generally yellowish, with a reddish tint possible on the dorsal and anal fins.

patterns: Distinct bright yellow lateral stripe extending from the mouth to the base of the tail.
Faint blue spots sometimes present on the upper flanks, scattered irregularly.
distinctive_features: Deeply forked, entirely yellow tail fin.
Sloping head profile.
Relatively large eyes.

visual_description.prompt_additions: Yellowtail Snapper, Ocyurus chrysurus, coral reef environment, bright yellow stripe, forked yellow tail, schooling fish.

colors.primary: Anterior half of body: Deep chocolate brown to black
colors.secondary: Posterior half of body: Bright yellow to orange-yellow
colors.accents: Thin, bright blue line outlining the operculum (gill cover). Small black spot at the base of the dorsal fin's last spine.

patterns: Sharp, distinct demarcation line between the dark anterior and bright posterior coloration, typically located around the mid-body.
Juveniles may exhibit more extensive blue markings or a less defined color transition.
distinctive_features: Oval body shape, slightly compressed laterally.
Single nostril opening on each side of the snout (characteristic of damselfish).
Relatively large eyes in proportion to body size.
Continuous dorsal fin with both spines and soft rays.

colors.primary: Silvery, with a slightly darker dorsal region.
colors.secondary: None specified, assume lighter silver on ventral side.
colors.accents: Possible faint iridescent sheen in blues and greens under certain lighting conditions.

patterns: No distinct patterns, but subtle variations in silver shading may be present along the lateral line.

Relatively large eyes in proportion to head size.
Streamlined, elongated body shape.
Slightly protruding lower jaw.

Adults may exhibit subtle darker blue vertical bars or striations along the body.

Small, protrusible mouth with a single row of teeth.
Scalpel-like spine (modified scale) located on the caudal peduncle (base of the tail), capable of being erected.
Continuous dorsal and anal fins running along most of the body length.
Lunate (crescent-shaped) tail fin in adults.

Thick, fleshy lips.

colors.primary: Dorsal surface: Slate grey to dark grey.
colors.secondary: Ventral surface: Bright white, sharply demarcated from the grey sides.
colors.accents: None, except for potential slight darkening at the tips of the fins in some individuals.

patterns: Countershading: Dark grey dorsally blending abruptly into bright white ventrally. This creates a camouflage effect.
No distinct spots or stripes.
distinctive_features: First dorsal fin: Large, triangular, and moderately falcate (curved). Originates over or slightly behind the pectoral fin insertion.
Second dorsal fin: Significantly smaller than the first dorsal fin, originating slightly ahead of the anal fin.
Pectoral fins: Large and triangular.
Caudal fin: Asymmetrical, with a well-developed upper lobe.
Snout: Short and broadly rounded.
Eyes: Relatively small and dark, lacking a nictitating membrane.

colors.primary: Grey to bluish-grey dorsally, transitioning to a lighter grey or off-white ventrally.
colors.accents: Dark grey to black vertical stripes and spots along the flanks, more prominent in juveniles and fading with age.

patterns: Vertical stripes and spots along the flanks, resembling a tiger's pattern, more pronounced in juveniles and fading as they mature. Stripes extend from the dorsal region towards the lateral line.
Countershading: Darker dorsal surface and lighter ventral surface for camouflage.
distinctive_features: Broad, blunt snout and head.
Highly serrated, cockscomb-shaped teeth visible even when the mouth is closed.
Relatively long pectoral fins.
Prominent keel on the caudal peduncle (the narrow part of the body just before the tail).

colors.secondary: Pale grey to silvery ventral area
colors.accents: Small reddish-brown spots scattered across the body and fins; faint yellow tinge on the dorsal and anal fin edges.

patterns: Marbled pattern formed by irregular dark brown or olive-green blotches and lines on the body, extending onto the dorsal and anal fins.

distinctive_features: Laterally compressed body shape.
Small, protrusible mouth.
Spinous rays present in the dorsal and anal fins (characteristic of spinefoots).

Small scales covering the entire body.

colors.secondary: Variable amounts of white ventrally, ranging from almost entirely black to almost entirely white
colors.accents: Tan or reddish-brown coloration from diatom accumulation, particularly on the ventral surface and flippers; White markings on flippers and tail flukes, unique to each individual

patterns: Irregular white patches and mottling on the ventral surface, extending onto the flanks in some individuals. The pattern is unique to each whale and used for identification.
Barnacles (off-white to greyish-white) are often attached to the skin, particularly on the head, pectoral fins, and ventral surface.
Callosities (raised, roughened skin patches) are present on the head and jaws, each containing one or more hairs. These appear off-white or yellowish due to whale lice.
distinctive_features: Extremely long pectoral fins, up to 1/3 of the body length, with irregular trailing edges.
Knobby tubercles (bumps) on the head and jaws, each containing a single hair follicle.
Deeply pleated throat grooves (ventral grooves) extending from the chin to the navel.
Small dorsal fin, often triangular or falcate (sickle-shaped), located about two-thirds of the way down the back.
Large, broad tail flukes with serrated trailing edges and a distinctive notch in the center. The fluke pattern is unique to each individual.
visual_description.body_shape: Robust body shape, relatively stocky compared to other rorquals. Possesses a distinct hump in front of the dorsal fin, giving the species its name. Body tapers towards the tail.
visual_description.prompt_additions: Humpback whale, Megaptera novaeangliae, long pectoral fins, knobby head, pleated throat, barnacles, unique fluke pattern, breaching, ocean setting.

colors.secondary: Variable mottling ranging from light tan to dark brown
colors.accents: Black (pupils)

Darker brown or reddish-brown patches concentrated around the eyes and arm bases.

Capable of dramatic color and texture changes.

Five pairs of walking legs, the first pair being slightly smaller than the others.

colors.accents: Iridescent blue or green spots along the flanks, more prominent in males. Fins may have reddish or orange tinges, especially during breeding season.

patterns: Irregular dark brown or black blotches and saddles along the back and sides.
Faint dark bars or stripes may be present on the flanks, more visible in juveniles.
Males often exhibit brighter and more contrasting patterns, including more intense spotting and darker bars.
distinctive_features: Fused pelvic fins forming a distinct ventral suction disc.
Relatively large head compared to body size.
Slightly flattened body shape, adapted for bottom dwelling.
Two separate dorsal fins; the first dorsal fin is shorter and spiny, the second is longer and soft-rayed.
Thick lips.
visual_description.body_shape: Elongated, cylindrical body, slightly flattened ventrally. Head is large and blunt. Tapers towards the tail.
visual_description.prompt_additions: Small, bottom-dwelling goby with olive-brown coloration, iridescent blue spots, and a ventral suction disc. Found in freshwater streams and rivers.

colors.primary: Dark grey to grey dorsally, transitioning to white ventrally.
colors.accents: Bright white margins on the tips and trailing edges of the dorsal fin, pectoral fins, pelvic fins, and caudal fin. Sometimes a faint reddish hue present on the fin tips when viewed underwater.

patterns: No distinct patterns beyond the countershading (dark grey/grey dorsally to white ventrally).
Faint lateral line visible along the body.
distinctive_features: Prominent white margins on all fins, especially the dorsal and pectoral fins.
Relatively large and broad first dorsal fin.
Streamlined, fusiform body shape.
Dark, relatively small eyes positioned laterally.
Powerful jaws with sharp, serrated teeth (visible when mouth is open).
visual_description.body_shape: Streamlined, fusiform (torpedo-shaped) body, typical of requiem sharks. Robust build, slightly more bulky than a grey reef shark.
visual_description.prompt_additions: Silvertip shark, white fin tips, streamlined body, coral reef environment, powerful predator.

colors.primary: Grey to grey-brown dorsally, transitioning to lighter grey laterally.
colors.accents: Jet black tips on the pectoral fins, dorsal fin (especially the first dorsal), pelvic fins, and caudal fin. The black coloration may extend as a narrow band along the trailing edges of these fins.

patterns: Countershading: Darker grey/grey-brown dorsally blending into a white or off-white underside.
Black tips/edges on fins: Distinct black markings on the tips and trailing edges of the pectoral, dorsal, pelvic, and caudal fins. The extent of the black varies between individuals and populations.
distinctive_features: Pointed snout, longer than the width of the mouth.
Relatively long gill slits.
No interdorsal ridge (ridge between the two dorsal fins).
Streamlined, fusiform (torpedo-shaped) body.
Relatively large, dark eyes.
visual_description.body_shape: Streamlined and fusiform, built for speed and agility. Moderately stout, not overly slender.
visual_description.prompt_additions: Blacktip shark, streamlined body, grey dorsally, white underside, black fin tips, pointed snout, no interdorsal ridge, coastal waters.

colors.primary: Variable; can range from vibrant turquoise to emerald green, often with a mottled appearance.
colors.secondary: Pink to lavender hues frequently present on the ventral side (belly) and lower flanks.
colors.accents: Electric blue outlining scales, particularly on the dorsal region and around the operculum (gill cover). Bright pink or reddish-orange lips.

patterns: Mottled or marbled pattern across the body, with irregular patches of darker and lighter shades of blue and green.
Scale margins often highlighted with a contrasting color (e.g., blue scales with darker green edges).
Some individuals may exhibit faint vertical barring, especially when young or stressed.
distinctive_features: Fused beak-like teeth, forming a prominent, parrot-like mouth.
Robust, oval-shaped body.
Slightly concave forehead profile.
Lunate (crescent-shaped) caudal fin (tail fin) in mature individuals.

visual_description.prompt_additions: Surf parrotfish, Scarus rivulatus, turquoise and pink, beak-like mouth, lunate tail, mottled scales, electric blue accents, robust body.

colors.secondary: White to off-white ventrally, creating a countershaded appearance
colors.accents: Slightly darker grey tips on dorsal and caudal fins may be present. Eyes are dark brown to black.

patterns: No distinct patterns; coloration is generally uniform. Subtle shading from dark grey/brown dorsally to white ventrally.
distinctive_features: Short, blunt snout, noticeably shorter and blunter than many other requiem sharks.
Relatively small eyes compared to body size, positioned high on the head.
First dorsal fin is large and triangular, originating over or slightly behind the pectoral fin free tips.
Second dorsal fin is significantly smaller than the first.
Pectoral fins are moderately long and falcate (sickle-shaped).
visual_description.body_shape: Robust and streamlined, typical of requiem sharks. Body is thick and heavy, tapering towards the tail. Appears bulky and powerful.
visual_description.prompt_additions: Pigeye shark, Carcharhinus amboinensis, short blunt snout, small eyes, large first dorsal fin, countershaded coloration, murky water environment

colors.primary: Highly variable; ranges from mottled brown and grey to reddish-brown, often with iridescent sheens.
colors.accents: Dark brown or black spots and bars that can appear and disappear rapidly; iridescent blue or green highlights possible, especially during display.

patterns: Mottled camouflage pattern across the dorsal mantle, adapting to the substrate.
Transverse dark bars can appear across the mantle, especially during stress or mating displays.
Fine speckling of dark pigment across the dorsal surface.
Wavy, white or pale line along the ventral edge of the mantle fin.

Undulating fin fringe extending almost the entire length of the mantle.
Eight arms with suckers, arranged in pairs.
Two longer tentacles, usually retracted into pouches beneath the eyes, with club-shaped ends covered in suckers.

Continuous dorsal fin with spines and soft rays.
Caudal fin is forked.

colors.secondary: Translucent, with subtle variations in pink intensity

Faint transverse bands of darker pink on the abdominal segments
White or cream-colored spots may be present on the pleopods (swimming legs)

colors.primary: Dorsal surface: Dark gray to grayish-brown.
colors.secondary: Ventral surface: Pale gray to white or tan.

patterns: Subtle countershading: Darker dorsal surface gradually fades to a lighter ventral surface.

Tall, sickle-shaped (falcate) first dorsal fin.
Strongly falcate (sickle-shaped) pelvic fins.

White or light grey margin along the leading edge of the pectoral fins (wings).

Pronounced cephalic fins (head fins) located on either side of the mouth, which can be unfurled to direct water into the mouth during feeding.

Numerous small eyes: A row of tiny, iridescent blue eyes are located along the mantle edge.

colors.primary: Variable, ranging from mottled brown and grey to vibrant yellow, orange, and purple depending on mood and environment.
colors.secondary: Often displays iridescent blue or green highlights, particularly along the mantle and arms.
colors.accents: Dark brown or black spots and bars can appear and disappear rapidly across the body. White or pale yellow highlights around the eyes and fin fringe are common.

patterns: Rapidly changing mottled patterns across the mantle, used for camouflage and communication.
Dark brown or black transverse bars that appear and disappear along the dorsal mantle.
Iridescent blue or green shimmering effect, especially prominent during displays.
White or pale yellow edging along the undulating fin fringe.
distinctive_features: W-shaped pupils.
Undulating fin fringe that extends almost the entire length of the mantle.
Eight arms of similar length, covered in suckers.
Two longer tentacles, usually retracted but rapidly extendable for prey capture. These tentacles have club-shaped ends covered in suckers.
Relatively small size compared to other cuttlefish species.
visual_description.body_shape: Elongated oval mantle, flattened dorsoventrally. The body is relatively slender compared to other cuttlefish. The head is distinct from the mantle, with prominent eyes.
visual_description.prompt_additions: Mourning cuttlefish, Ascarosepion plangon, displaying camouflage, undulating fin fringe, W-shaped pupils, iridescent highlights, Australia

colors.primary: Light to dark brown, often with a reddish tinge
colors.secondary: Translucent or pale cream-colored legs and underside
colors.accents: Dark brown or black transverse bands across the carapace and abdomen; Coral-colored uropods and telson (tail fan)

patterns: Distinct dark brown/black transverse bands (tiger stripes) across the dorsal surface of the carapace and abdomen. Bands are more prominent on the abdomen.
Small, scattered dark brown spots may be present on the carapace.
distinctive_features: Rostrum (horn-like projection between the eyes) with 7-9 dorsal teeth and 2-4 ventral teeth.
Relatively long antennae, often exceeding the body length.
Well-developed pleopods (swimming legs) on the abdomen.
Prominent uropods and telson forming a tail fan.
visual_description.body_shape: Elongated, laterally compressed body; curved abdomen; tapering rostrum.
visual_description.prompt_additions: Translucent legs, tiger-striped abdomen, long antennae, coral-colored tail fan

colors.accents: Pale orange or pink near the hinge

patterns: Approximately 18-22 rounded ribs radiating from the hinge to the outer edge of the shell
Faint concentric growth rings visible between the ribs
distinctive_features: Equivalve (both valves are similar in shape), but inequilateral (hinge is not in the center)
Rounded, fan-shaped shell
Small 'ears' (auricles) on either side of the hinge, relatively equal in size
Fine radial striations on the ribs
visual_description.body_shape: Fan-shaped, bivalve shell with rounded ribs
visual_description.prompt_additions: Coral-colored scallop with rounded ribs, fan-shaped shell, small ears near the hinge

colors.secondary: Pale coral pink or orange-tinged brown
colors.accents: Dark brown or reddish-brown concentric lines

patterns: Concentric growth rings visible as fine, dark brown or reddish-brown lines across the shell surface.
Irregular blotches or streaks of pale coral pink or orange-tinged brown, concentrated near the umbo (hinge) of the shell.
distinctive_features: Relatively thick, wedge-shaped shell (hence 'cuneimeris').
Prominent umbo (hinge) slightly anterior to the midline.
Fine radial ribs visible under magnification, intersecting with the concentric growth lines.
Internal shell surface (nacre) is typically white and glossy.
visual_description.body_shape: Wedge-shaped bivalve shell, with a rounded anterior end and a more pointed posterior end. Valves are roughly equilateral.
visual_description.prompt_additions: Wedge-shaped bivalve shell, creamy white with pale coral pink blotches and dark brown concentric lines. Found on coral reefs.

colors.secondary: Coral or light orange-pink (may be present on ribs or aperture)
colors.accents: Dark brown or black (possible operculum color)

patterns: Axial ribs: Prominent, raised ribs running vertically along the shell's length. These ribs are sharply defined.
Spiral cords: Faint spiral cords or ridges crossing the axial ribs, creating a textured surface.
Aperture: Interior of the aperture (shell opening) may be a contrasting color, such as coral or light orange-pink.
distinctive_features: Sharp, well-defined axial ribs (hence the name).
Relatively small, oval-shaped aperture.
Short siphonal canal (the small channel extending from the aperture).
Spire: Conical spire, moderately elevated.
visual_description.body_shape: Elongated oval, conical shell with a distinct spire. Solid and robust.
visual_description.prompt_additions: Small, sharp-ribbed sea snail with creamy white shell and possible coral accents. Found on coral reefs. Show prominent axial ribs and a short siphonal canal.

colors.secondary: Creamy white or pale yellow on ventral side and leg joints
colors.accents: Darker green or brown mottling on the carapace; tips of chelae (claws) may be orange or reddish-brown

patterns: Mottled or marbled pattern of darker green/brown on the dorsal carapace, providing camouflage
Faint transverse ridges or lines across the carapace
distinctive_features: Broad, trapezoidal carapace with prominent anterolateral teeth (spines) - typically 6 on each side, including the outer orbital tooth
Paddle-shaped dactylus (terminal segment) on the last pair of legs, adapted for swimming
Relatively large chelae (claws) with granular texture and sharp teeth on the cutting edges
Frontal margin of the carapace with four distinct lobes or teeth
visual_description.body_shape: Broad and flattened carapace, trapezoidal in dorsal view. The body is wider than it is long. The legs are relatively long and slender, except for the paddle-shaped swimming legs.
visual_description.prompt_additions: Swimming crab, broad carapace, paddle-shaped rear legs, mottled green-brown coloration, prominent anterolateral spines.

colors.secondary: Deep purple or black longitudinal stripes
colors.accents: Orange or yellow border along the mantle edge and around the gill plumes; Rhinophores are orange or yellow

patterns: Three to five (typically four) distinct longitudinal stripes running along the length of the dorsum (back). Stripes are solid and evenly spaced.
Mantle edge is bordered with a continuous orange or yellow band.
Gill plumes are arranged in a circle around the anus, with orange or yellow tips.
distinctive_features: Nudibranch: lacks a shell.
Elongated oval body shape.
Rhinophores (sensory organs) located on the head, appearing as small, antenna-like structures. They are lamellate (layered).
Feathery gill plumes located posteriorly on the dorsal surface, forming a branchial plume.
Smooth mantle surface.
visual_description.body_shape: Elongated oval, flattened dorsoventrally. The body is soft and flexible.
visual_description.prompt_additions: Chromodoris magnifica nudibranch, translucent white body with deep purple longitudinal stripes, orange mantle border, orange rhinophores and gills, smooth texture.

colors.accents: White or pale yellow rhinophores and gills (details may vary)

patterns: Reticulate (net-like) pattern of pinkish-purple gradually merging into the pale lavender-purple base color, concentrated towards the mantle edge.
White or pale yellow margin around the mantle edge (may be broken or incomplete).
distinctive_features: Pair of lamellate rhinophores (sensory organs) on the head, typically white or pale yellow.
Feathery gills arranged in a circle on the posterior dorsal surface, typically white or pale yellow.
Smooth, elongated body shape typical of nudibranchs.
Mantle (outer edge of the body) extending slightly beyond the foot.
visual_description.body_shape: Elongated, soft-bodied nudibranch with a flattened profile. The mantle extends slightly beyond the foot.
visual_description.prompt_additions: Lavender Split-tooth Dorid nudibranch, Hypselodoris bullockii, pale purple body, pinkish-purple reticulated pattern, white rhinophores and gills, smooth mantle.

colors.primary: Translucent amber, ranging from light yellow-brown to reddish-brown
colors.secondary: Interior nacre is pearlescent white with iridescent sheen
colors.accents: May have darker brown or reddish-brown growth lines

patterns: Irregular growth lines running parallel to the shell margin
Radial striations extending from the pointed umbo (hinge) towards the flared margin
distinctive_features: Triangular, elongated shell shape resembling a quill or pen nib
Fragile, thin shell structure
Shell surface may be encrusted with algae or other marine organisms
Pointed umbo (hinge) embedded in the substrate, with the flared margin extending upwards
visual_description.body_shape: Elongated triangular, fan-shaped bivalve shell
visual_description.prompt_additions: Translucent amber pen shell, triangular shape, embedded in coral reef substrate, fragile shell, iridescent interior.

colors.secondary: Cream or light tan on the aperture and interior of the shell
colors.accents: Darker reddish-brown on the spines and ridges

patterns: Spiral ridges running along the shell's surface, more pronounced on the later whorls.
Spines projecting outwards from the shell, particularly prominent on the siphonal canal and shoulder of the whorls. These spines may be slightly darker than the main shell color.
Irregular growth lines visible across the shell surface.
distinctive_features: Elongated siphonal canal, often slightly curved.
Relatively large aperture with a toothed outer lip.
Spirally arranged varices (raised ridges) on each whorl, giving the shell a knobby appearance.
Shell surface may exhibit a slightly rough or textured appearance.
visual_description.body_shape: Fusiform (spindle-shaped) shell with a high spire and an elongated siphonal canal.
visual_description.prompt_additions: Close-up of an adusta murex (Chicoreus brunneus) sea snail. Show the coral red shell with darker spines, cream aperture, and elongated siphonal canal. Found on a coral reef.

colors.accents: Bright orange or yellow

patterns: Longitudinal deep purple or violet stripes running along the length of the body, typically broken or irregular.
Bright orange or yellow margin around the mantle edge.
Rhinophores (antennae-like structures on the head) are translucent white with orange or yellow tips.
Gills are translucent white with orange or yellow tips and edges.
distinctive_features: Nudibranch with exposed gills forming a branchial plume on the posterior end.
Two prominent rhinophores on the head, used for chemoreception.
Smooth, elongated body shape.
Mantle (outer edge of the body) extends slightly beyond the foot.
visual_description.body_shape: Elongated, slug-like, dorsoventrally flattened
visual_description.prompt_additions: Nudibranch, Hypselodoris zephyra, translucent white body, purple stripes, orange margin, feathery gills, rhinophores

colors.secondary: Creamy white or pale yellow on ventral side
colors.accents: Darker olive green or brown mottling on carapace; tips of walking legs may have reddish-brown hues

patterns: Irregular mottling or speckling of darker olive green/brown across the dorsal carapace surface, providing camouflage.
Faint transverse ridges or lines may be present on the carapace.
distinctive_features: Paddle-shaped dactyls (terminal segments) on the last pair of pereiopods (swimming legs), significantly broadened for swimming.
Broad, transversely oval carapace, wider than long.
Relatively long and slender walking legs (pereiopods 1-4) compared to other swimming crabs.
Well-developed anterolateral teeth (spines) on the carapace margin, typically 4-5 on each side.
visual_description.body_shape: Broadly oval and flattened carapace; streamlined for swimming. Carapace is wider than it is long. The body is dorsoventrally compressed.
visual_description.prompt_additions: Swimming crab, paddle-shaped rear legs, broad carapace, mottled olive green and brown, slender walking legs.

colors.primary: Variable, ranging from crimson red to olive green and coral pink, depending on environment and mood.
colors.secondary: Often mottled with lighter shades of primary color, creating a camouflage effect.
colors.accents: May display iridescent blue or purple highlights in skin texture when agitated or displaying.

patterns: Mottled camouflage pattern across mantle and arms, adapting to the surrounding reef environment.
May exhibit darker bands or spots on arms for disruptive coloration.
Skin texture can change rapidly, creating raised bumps or smooth surfaces, further enhancing camouflage.
distinctive_features: Large, prominent eyes with horizontal pupils, providing excellent vision.
Eight arms of varying length and diameter, covered in two rows of suckers.
Bulky mantle, proportionally large compared to arm length.
Highly textured skin capable of rapid color and texture changes.

visual_description.prompt_additions: Caribbean Reef Octopus, crimson to olive green, mottled camouflage, large eyes, textured skin, coral reef environment.

colors.secondary: Pale cream to light coral on the base and margins
colors.accents: Faint, irregular brown speckling may be present on the dorsal surface, particularly in older specimens.

Margins of the shell may exhibit a slightly darker coral hue compared to the central dorsal area.

Involute shell, meaning the outer whorls completely enclose the inner whorls.
Narrow, toothed aperture (opening) running along the ventral side.
Smooth, glossy texture, lacking prominent ridges or spines.

colors.secondary: Cream or pale yellow on the ventral surface and inner arms.
colors.accents: Darker red or brown spots and bands that can appear and disappear rapidly.

patterns: Mottled pattern across the mantle and arms, providing camouflage against reef environments.
Capable of displaying dark bands across the arms when threatened or hunting.
Papillae (small bumps) distributed irregularly across the skin, enhancing texture and camouflage.

Eight arms of roughly equal length, each covered in two rows of suckers.
Highly textured skin with numerous papillae and folds.

colors.accents: Orange or yellow rhinophores and gills; thin white margin around the mantle

patterns: Longitudinal deep blue or purple stripes running along the length of the dorsum (back), typically 3-5 stripes.

White or pale blue-white background color visible between the stripes.
Orange or yellow coloration concentrated on the tips of the rhinophores and the edges of the gills.
distinctive_features: Exposed, feathery gills arranged in a circle or semi-circle near the posterior end of the body.

Mantle edge is typically outlined with a thin white band.
visual_description.body_shape: Elongated oval, flattened dorsoventrally. Soft-bodied and flexible.
visual_description.prompt_additions: nudibranch, sea slug, Chromodoris lochi, Loch's chromodoris, translucent white body, deep blue stripes, orange rhinophores and gills, white mantle edge, feathery gills on back

colors.primary: Variable, ranging from pale cream to vibrant orange or reddish-brown.
colors.accents: Often has darker reddish-brown or purple-brown spots or blotches, particularly near the hinge and along the ribs.

patterns: Radial ribs, numbering approximately 20-25, extending from the hinge to the outer edge of the shell. These ribs are often slightly raised and may have fine transverse striations.
Irregular spots or blotches of darker reddish-brown or purple-brown scattered across the shell surface, concentrated near the hinge and along the ribs.
Concentric growth rings visible on the shell surface.
distinctive_features: Scalloped edge of the shell, characteristic of scallops.
Two valves (shells) that are roughly equal in size and shape.
Small 'eyes' or ocelli visible along the mantle edge (the soft tissue visible when the shell is slightly open). These are typically a dark color, such as black or dark brown.
Unequal auricles (ears) at the hinge; one is larger than the other.

visual_description.prompt_additions: Ornate scallop, fan-shaped shell, radial ribs, variable color (cream, orange, reddish-brown), dark spots, unequal auricles, Caribbean reef environment.

colors.accents: Numerous small, dark brown to black spots (measles) covering the entire dorsal surface. Base is white to cream.

patterns: Dense covering of small, dark brown to black spots (measles) across the entire dorsal surface of the shell.
Base of the shell is generally a uniform white to cream color, lacking spots.

Elongated, oval shell shape.
Narrow aperture (shell opening) with fine teeth along both lips.
Dorsal surface is highly convex.

colors.accents: Black

colors.secondary: Variable, ranging from pale pink to light orange
colors.accents: Irregular blotches or streaks of coral-pink or reddish-brown, particularly near the hinge and along the ribs.

patterns: Radial ribs: Approximately 20-30 prominent, rounded ribs radiating from the hinge to the outer edge of each valve.
Growth rings: Concentric growth rings visible on the surface of the valves, indicating age.
Blotches: Irregular blotches of coral-pink or reddish-brown, concentrated near the hinge and along the ribs. The intensity and distribution of these blotches vary significantly between individuals.
distinctive_features: Scalloped edge: The outer edge of each valve is distinctly scalloped, following the contours of the radial ribs.
Unequal valves: The two valves are slightly unequal in size and convexity, with the lower valve being slightly flatter.
Auricles: Small, ear-shaped projections (auricles) present on either side of the hinge. These are typically lighter in color than the rest of the valve.
visual_description.body_shape: Bivalve shell, roughly circular to oval in outline. Valves are moderately convex. The overall shape is typical of scallops.
visual_description.prompt_additions: Farrer's scallop, creamy white shell with coral-pink blotches, radial ribs, scalloped edge, bivalve.
